PHRPOSES OF THE EXPERIMENT
The questions which this initial exploration sought to answer were many. In
a broad general way, the hope was to discover ways to employ radio, TV and other
powerful mass media to strengthen rather than to weaken the position of the indi¬
vidual in a democratic society. Could the mass communication ’’gimmicks” that are
accused of creating a mass mind work instead to develop strong, independent think¬
ing citizens of a free society? (The answer to this question was a resounding
”Yes.”)
More specifically, the experiment sought information and answers to questions
which would be valuable in future, more extensive attempts to tie group discussion
and mass media together.
1. Could and would radio and newspaper - two of the most powerful means of
mass communication - work together in a joint educational program?
2. Would people form discussion groups on their own initiative to read the
newspaper articles and listen to the programs?
3. If so, what kinds of people would take the lead? What kinds of people
would come and where would they meet? Vlfhat different organizational approaches to
forming groups would turn up?
4. Would the groups formed last the full nine weeks or wither away after the
initial excitement died down?
5. What kinds of discussions would these groups hold, lacking trained lead¬
ers? Would quality of the discussion have to be sacrificed in order to achieve
Quantity? (The assumption was that this would be true; the results were a happy
contradiction.)
